verses.text: The words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah: In the month of Kislev in the twentieth year, while I was in the fortress city of Susa,
verses.comment: Nehemiah introduces himself and the setting, providing historical context. Susa was a prominent city of the Persian empire, also mentioned in Esther.

verses.text: Hanani, one of my brothers, and certain men from Judah came. I asked them about the Jews who had survived the exile and about Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Hanani, likely Nehemiah’s actual brother, brings news regarding the state of the remnant in Jerusalem. The concern for the people aligns with the theme of restoration found throughout the prophets.

verses.text: They replied, 'The remnant there in the province who survived the exile are in great trouble and shame. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates are destroyed by fire.'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s disgrace and vulnerability is emphasized. The broken walls symbolize lost protection. This evokes the spiritual restoration and healing that would later be fulfilled in Christ and His Church as the new Jerusalem.

verses.text: When I heard these words, I sat down and wept and mourned for days. I fasted and prayed before the God of heaven.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s response of mourning, fasting, and prayer shows his deep concern for God’s people. Fasting and prayer in times of crisis is a continual pattern across Scripture and in Church tradition for seeking divine intervention.

verses.text: I said, 'O LORD, God of heaven, the great and awesome God who keeps covenant and steadfast love with those who love Him and keep His commandments,
verses.comment: Nehemiah appeals to God’s covenant faithfulness, echoing language from Moses and Solomon’s prayers. Theological emphasis on covenant continuity is important, showing the unity of God’s plan throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Let your ear be attentive and your eyes open to hear the prayer of your servant that I now pray before you day and night for your servants, the people of Israel, confessing the sins of the people of Israel, which we have sinned against you. Both I and my father's house have sinned.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s intercessory prayer and confession parallels Daniel and Ezra, acknowledging corporate guilt. This highlights the necessity of communal confession and repentance, a practice carried forward into the new covenant.

verses.text: We have acted very wickedly against you and have not kept the commandments, the statutes, and the ordinances that you commanded your servant Moses.
verses.comment: The reference to Moses' law underscores continuity between Old and New Testament faithfulness and obedience to God’s commands, which takes on a fuller spiritual meaning in the teaching of Jesus.

verses.text: Remember the word that you commanded your servant Moses: 'If you are unfaithful, I will scatter you among the peoples,
verses.comment: Covenant consequences are cited, emphasizing God’s justice. Scattering was fulfilled in the Exile, foreshadowing eventual regathering and restoration, a theme that finds ultimate fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: but if you return to me, keep my commandments and do them, though your outcasts are in the farthest part of the heavens, I will gather them and bring them to the place I have chosen to make my name dwell there.'
verses.comment: God promises restoration upon repentance, gathering His people to the chosen place—Jerusalem. Spiritually, this points to the fullness of worship and reconciliation found in the new covenant assembly.

verses.text: They are your servants and your people whom you have redeemed by your great power and by your strong hand.
verses.comment: Redemption imagery is prominent here, recalling the Exodus. This anticipates the greater redemption brought about through Jesus, who delivers His people by His power.

verses.text: O Lord, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant and to the prayer of your servants who delight to fear your name. Give success to your servant today, and grant him mercy in the sight of this man.” Now I was cupbearer to the king.
verses.comment: Nehemiah closes his prayer seeking favor from God as he prepares to act on behalf of God's people. His role as cupbearer is notable—he is positioned for intercession and service, echoing the idea of mediation that will be realized in the ultimate Intercessor and Mediator, Jesus Christ.
